Award.AwardTitle: PRAC - Hierarchical molecular dynamics sampling for assessing pathways and free energies of RNA catalysis, ligand binding, and conformational change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award facilitates scientific research using the large, new, computational resource named Blue Waters being developed by IBM and scheduled to be deployed at the University of Illinois in 2011. It provides travel funds to support technical coordination between the principal investigators, the Blue Waters project team and the vendor technical team.

An experienced team of AMBER biomolecular simulation software developers with expertise ranging from QM/MM methods, enhanced sampling methods, code optimization and parallelization, and biomolecular simulation aim to enhance the AMBER software for optimal function on the Blue Waters machine. The intended application area involves RNA and the main goals are to hierarchically and tightly couple a series of optimized molecular dynamics engines to better map out the conformational, energetic and chemical landscape of RNA. The simulation engines will be optimized at the supernode level and will be coupled together and exchange information to better sample and interpret the free energy landscape. Broader impact and significance centers on ultimately providing a better understanding of RNA and protein structure, dynamics and function and the development, exploration, and integration of biomolecular simulation technologies to better understand and explore the structural, chemical and energetic landscapes of biomolecules. The latter impacts will translate to other application areas and emerging computer hardware.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project outcomes report is for the first of three PRAC awards awarded to our research team that applies biomolecular simulation methods, running ensembles of independent simulations that communicate information to increase efficiency of sampling conformational space, to provide insight into protein and nucleic acid structure, dynamics, and function. The award provided funds for travel within the United States and a 1-year allocation of computer time on the Blue Waters petascale resource.

When simulated with the applied enhanced sampling methodologies complete exploration and sampling of the accessible conformational space of the biomolecule becomes possible. We demonstrated the ability to converge the conformational distributions of the r(GACC) nucleotide and reduced the time scale of the simulations from months to days. The simulations help point us where to significantly improve force fields for nucleic acids and provided detailed mechanistic insight into biomolecular dynamics, structural changes, and function. The overall impact is a substantial improvement in force field fidelity coupled with detailed information regarding the simulation time scales required for true convergence of MD simulations. The work defined the benchmark for the field from which other simulations are measured and sampled conformational ensembles of biomolecules on a previously unprecedented scale and at a level of coverage that simply is not feasible experimentally or with conventional computational resources.

The methods and code, including multidimensional replica exchange and constant pH simulations, were disseminated with AMBER 14 and AmberTools 14, both available at http://www.ambermd.org.
